data.text:
Hi Everyone!

Welcome to Let’s Deconstruct a Story! This month I’m talking to Katherine Vaz about her wonderful story, “Our Lady of the Artichokes.” Please read the story (below) before tuning into the podcast available on Apple, Spotify, or wherever you get your podcasts.

Also, please check out the link to her fantastic new novel Above the Salt which I read and adored. Sometimes I really wish this was also a podcast about novels, but we do offer a brief preview of the book during our discussion. Purchase options available below.

Next month I’ll be talking to Jai Chakrabarti about his story, “A Small Sacrifice for an Enormous Happiness,” which is available here. If you have any questions for Jai, feel free to contact me and I will pass them along.

Have a wonderful holiday season. I’ll be reaching out in two weeks with some end of the year recommendations and then we’ll see you on January 1st for Jai Chakrabarti.

Cheers!

Kelly

Bio:

Katherine Vaz, a former Briggs-Copeland Fellow in Fiction at Harvard, Fellow of the Radcliffe Institute, and a National Endowment for the Arts recipient, has published two novels, SAUDADE and MARIANA. The latter appeared in six languages and was selected by the Library of Congress as one of the Top Thirty International Books of 1998. Film rights are optioned by Harrison Productions, with Sandy Welch contracted to do the screenplay.

Vaz’s collection FADO & OTHER STORIES won the Drue Heinz Literature Prize, and OUR LADY OF THE ARTICHOKES won the Prairie Schooner Book Prize, and her multi-media artbook THE HEART IS A DROWNING OBJECT, with artist Isabel Pavão, was released by Artist’s Proof Editions in 2019. Her short fiction has appeared in dozens of magazines, including Tin House, BOMB, The Harvard Review, Gargoyle, Glimmer Train, The Common, Ninth Letter, The Antioch Review etc., and her children’s stories are included in several anthologies from Viking and Simon & Schuster.

ABOVE THE SALT, a novel, is due in Fall, 2023 from Flatiron Books/Macmillan, film representation with Rich Green of Gotham Group. She is the first Portuguese American to have her work recorded for the archives of the Library of Congress (Hispanic Division) and was listed by the Portuguese American Leadership Conference of the U.S. as one of the all-time most influential Lusa women. She has published many short stories, including some in anthologies for children, and lives in New York City with her husband Christopher Cerf, son of Bennett Cerf, the founder of Random House. Christopher is an editor, TV producer, and former Sesame Street composer and writer.

Above the Salt is available from Bookshop here and Amazon here.
